productDescription: The Home Audio System that you will love. The Mondo+ connects to your Wi-Fi network in 2 minutes via the 3.5” color display, no special app required to set up or play!

While no app is required, we do have a cool iPhone/Android app. Control every Mondo+ from any room in your home! Play different music on each Mondo+ or the same music perfectly synchronized all through your house.

The Mondo+ supports over 30,000 direct access AM/FM/HD internet radio stations and podcast, including BBC, NPR, CBS, or stream directly directly from the hundreds of Chromecast enabled apps via Wi-Fi or use Bluetooth when you are away from home.
Do you use a premium music provider? Check out our list of partners below.

Listen to SiriusXM, Spotify Connect (contact SiriusXM or Spotify for subscriptions) as well as stream Chromecast enabled apps directly from your smartphone such as Pandora, iHeartRadio, TuneIn, Google Play Music, YOUTUBE Music, NPR One, Tidal, Slacker, Deezer and hundreds more.
And while we have an extensive station and podcast database, if we don’t have your favorite station, just let us know and we will add it for you!

The Mondo+ also supports Chromecast mirroring – any audio you are playing in your Chromecast browser can be mirrored and cast to a Grace Mondo+! We even support playing your music saved on any standard UPnP media server or thumb drive.
The Mondo+ even integrates Bluetooth 4.1 for music streaming when you are away from your Wi-Fi connection.
The large color 3.5” display makes for easy navigation through the menus, settings, and apps on the Mondo+. While streaming music, view the channel or album artwork, song title, and artist name.

Don’t have your smartphone handy, no worries, control your Mondo+ directly from the front panel or included infrared remote. Save and play up to 10 presets, set the alarm, sleep timer, snooze bar, back light settings. Even change the name of your Mondo+ to a name like Bedroom, Kitchen, Den for a whole home multi-radio experience.

The optional rechargeable Lithium Ion battery, sold separately, makes the Mondo+ portable. Move it into various rooms or even to listen to music in your backyard without having to plug in. The optional battery allows for up to 12 hours of portable play via normal listening levels (5 hours at max volume). Battery specs: 7V, 5200 mAh.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
Nice display, very good sound. The Mondo+ utilizes Google Chromecast which is a plus for many, but also has it's drawbacks. As an owner of a previous Logitech and Mondo, there are apps missing from the plus that are worth pointing out to new potential buyers. Keep in mind this may change with a software update, but as I write this, these apps are not included:

*No Pandora
*No Tunein Radio
*No Live365
*No Slacker
*No Spotify
*No AccuRadio
*No ShoutCast
*No RadioTunes

The Mondo+ does offer the following out of the box:

*Sirius
*iHeart Radio
*NPR and Public Radio
*BBC
*CBS Radio
*Podcast by Audiosear

The other negative to this radio involves the internet radio. On my previous Logitech UE radio, I would select music, then type of genre and it would bring up a list of stations local and around the world that matched the music I was looking for. On the Mondo+, there are more steps involved in finding your music using search by genre. For example, if you want to find Rock stations here is what you have to do if you do not know the name of the station you are searching for:

1) Select Internet Radio
2) Select Search for Station by Genre
3) Select the genre you like - Example - Rock
4) Select the Region and scroll through the list and select one - Asia, Europe, Middle East, North America, South America and Oceania
5) If you select North America, you now have to scroll through the list of countries or territories and select one like the United States for example
6) If you selected the United States, you now have to select the state or zip code and it will bring up the list of stations that match your genre search

As far as I'm concerned, this requires too many added steps to find genre stations without knowing the name. The short cut to this is to search by name and just type in 'Rock' and it will bring up a list of rock stations and this makes it easier than doing a genre search.

In addition, there are music genres that seem to be missing from the genre list on the Mondo+. My previous Logitech had more music options in the scroll list. For example, missing from the genre list of the Mondo+ is the following:

*60's
*Ambient
*Bluegrass
*Blues
*Bollywood
*Children's Music
*Christmas Music
*Classic Hits
*Classic Rock
*College Radio
*Decades
*Easy listening
*Eclectic
*Indie
*Live Music
*New Age
*Reggae

These genres will have to be searched for. There is an option for 'other music' but I did not find any folders that contained any of the music listed above. Perhaps Grace will add these back in a later date. Until that happens, you will have to rely on the search feature.

I will assume that future updates will make this radio better and perhaps Grace Digital will add the apps that now missing. If you don't care about any of those missing apps I listed above, this is a very good radio with great sound, but it's not as feature rich as the older Logitech UE radio and requires some more input to get what you are looking for. For that reason, it's two steps forward and a big step back.

What a great Internet Radio! The sound is very, very good, my stations are programmable, it has 10 presets and a remote, and best of all, this is a quality unit. I bought this to replace an aging Squeezebox, which is slowly having more problems, but I also own two other Internet radios, and the Mondo+ is the best of the lot. I love the large readouts, and the time shows when the radio is off. This radio also gets Sirius XM (I have that in my car only at this time), and with Bluetooth and a USB slot, I can't think of what else it could need.

I found this was easy to set up, used the Internet to add stations to "My Stuff," and Mondo+ connected easily to my Wi-Fi using the onboard Wizard. My current passion is Old Time Radio and most of those broadcasts sound great with the radio's speakers, no difficulties at all. There is one small complaint, and that is the preset buttons do not light up and that would be helpful as I like to listen at night, but the other attributes make up for it. I would not hesitate to recommend this radio to anyone looking for a fine Internet Radio.

This radio will play Sirius subscription satellite radio and most everything else that is free or subscription on the internet. We connect via WiFi. When my long term Sirius radio died and I discovered that Sirius no longer has a radio I found this radio. The people on the phone at Sirius did not know that the their radios were out and there were other options such as this. The Grace radio has a full sound for a small radio and has a user friendly LED screen user interface. And you can tune in most anything with crystal clear sound by way of the stations web site which most stations support. It does not tune in the traditional way by frequency. Our house keeper who is employed by us listens to Poland. I listen to the Beatles channel and our Mobrella Cockatoo blooms out in full color at rock and roll and hangs upside down singing. The extra $ rechargeable battery dies too quickly. And some times some strange screens come up that puzzles me on the led. When I first got it it took me a half hour to find the volume control which is this big cylindrical protrusion out the top that looks like a big snooze button. It is actually very handy. So bottom line is so far so good. Actually great. Needs a better rechargeable battery which by the way is an extra $ option. There is a buffer time period which the user can choose in the settings to avoid sudden cut outs. The odd side to that if you too hurriedly turn the radio on and then wish to suddenly turn off you may not be able to if it is buffering. I would say that anyone having had a Sirius internet in home radio that was dedicated only to Sirius and had a number of problems will love this. It handles
the world and appears to be reliable and much more user friendly with the LED screen. Surprising that Sirius operators know nothing about this. Didn’t have a clue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sound keeps cutting off. Crickets from their support.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this radio for my daughter as a gift. She loves to have classical music playing while she sleeps. This radio provides an great number of stations for her to listen to. Unfortunately the sound in this radio cuts out most nights. To get the sound to return I have to change the station, or sometimes power off/on the radio. My network is very reliable, I only have a problem with this product. I sent in a query to support and haven't heard anything after four days. I really want to like this product, but I expect better reliability and support for the price paid. I've looked on the support site and I see mention of this issue, but the radio always says it doesn't have a firmware update when I check.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you want a good radio that dies in 2 days . . .
reviews.reviewText: If you want a good radio that dies in 2 days then this is the one for you. Out of the box two evenings ago, the evening spent setting it up. It worked and sounds great. It died in two days. Grace Digital support had me factory reset, wiping out all I'd accomplished setting it up. Still didn't work, so I was advised to contact Amazon for a replacement. Amazon will ship me another, arriving in another two days and I can start all over, be back where I was two evenings ago. Not a happy Mondo+ customer, to say the least. Maybe I should have cancelled the replacement, taken a straight refund until Grace Digital works the bugs out, gone with another brand. Time will tell, apparently.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it, but with some reservations, read my comments and decide for yourself
reviews.reviewText:
I love it with some reservations. The firs thing is that I really liked it from the first I got it. i have had it for more than a few years now. The first thing that went wrong was the battery went dead. It is a rechargeable pack that helps the radio work if the power goes out, so you are not late for work. That battery pack is not cheap. ait appears that they could have allowed the Mondo to use batteries that can be bought anywhere, but they did not. This may bean extra cost that they worked into the product.
I got past the battery replacement and went a couple of years later before I bought a sound bar for my TV with a subwoofer. It had a remote that would interact with the Mondo. That should not happen, shame on you Grace Digital for not making sure that the Mondo would not interact with other remote controls from other devices. That was a Vizio sound bar.
Now i am retired, and I like to fall asleep listing to iHeart radio, The Vinyl Experience, it is a great station to listen to. I plug headphones into my Mpondo, and after so many times of doing that, the headphone jack went bad. It still puts audio out, it is just that if you remove them, the speaker does not come back on. Grace Digital wants $32.99, plus i have to pack it up and ship it. So add another $10 to that. I am a technician, so I took the Mondo apart and am now looking for a replacement headphone jack that will fit the radio. If i don't find one, I will use what i have and epoxy it to stay where i need it to be. All in all, if i lost this Mondo, i would buy another. I have other Internet radios that have features that make them great, but the Mondo feels at home at the bedside as an alarm clock that will play anything.
Lastly, the Mondo has RCA jacks on the back, so you can feed the sound to your stereo system. The Wifi on it works very well from one side of my home, all the way to the other.

reviews.reviewTitle: New functionalities to an almost perfect device!
reviews.reviewText:
This review is of the new digital Mondo PLUS.
I am changing my original review after talking with the company as I was explained about the issues I mentioned. I had a problem with the display that was not perfectly aligned but the Company will sort out the issue.
Since the product was completely re- engineered in terms of software, some of the functionalities that i mentioned before will be modified in next updates (specifically the sleep mode and station browsing).
From what regards using the radio as a Sonos speaker, it cannot. Although the device could be integrated into a home audio system and used as a zone/room speaker with its chromecast functionality. The sound quality is quite good for up to a medium sized room.
I still would like to be able to play music from my amazon music account.

----
I have been using the original mondo for several years. Great product, no problem, working flawlessly after more than 3 years. When the new mondo plus came out i decided to go for it immediately, mainly because it had bluetooth and the chromecast feature so I could use spotify.
The radio is still great product but my experience have some drawback compared to the original mondo:
- When the screen is dimmed, on standby, you cannot see the time when you are facing the radio horizontally (at the same height). i.e I have it on my nightstand and i have to stand up to see the hour. This does not happen on my previous mondo.
- The sleep function cannot be used from the smartphone app.
- The internet radio search function has no hierarchy inside the countries, you look for stations from a certain country and you get hundreds of radio station with no filter.
- I read somewhere that the radio in addition to bluetooth could be uses as a sonos speaker, so far I have not been able to add it to my sonos system. Also the mondo plus has no am/fm receiver, contrary to what I thought by reading the description.

reviews.reviewTitle: Garbage. And hard to use. Want to return.
reviews.reviewText:
Absolute garbage.
Not user friendly at all. I'm pretty tech savvy and it is STILL a pain to program and navigate the menus. It's always disconnecting from wifi which forces you to wake up to annoying beeping instead of music and most times just doesn't even go off. I want to return it but of course the return window is closed.

I bought this radio to use primarily as an internet tuner using RCA audio out ports in a home stereo system. It replaces a previous Grace tuner only device that failed after about four years and which Grace no longer markets or supports and now seems to be the only device on the market that can function in this task.
The radio is an update of a previously marketed Grace radio. It works OK for tuning wifi stations but does not have built in apps for Pandora, I-Heart, Spotify or Google Play so those venues must be "cast" from a phone or tablet to the device using a built-in Chromecast. Herein lies the problem. Not only do you need another active device but the Chromecast is unreliable. Google Play works OK but I have yet to be able to receive Pandora.
Gracetech's answer to this was to reboot the various devices several times and, when this didn't work, to say that sometimes the Mondo+ radios don't work well with Apple products.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would be perfect if it still had the Pandora app actually on the radio itself
reviews.reviewText:
This is my third Mondo radio purchase--I had previously bought one for myself and one for my mom. My most recent purchase is my first Mondo + , and I'm disappointed that the new one has no Pandora app. Reading the comments here I see that Pandora is to blame for this, not Grace Digital. Pandora now requires new devices to use a streaming technology such as Chromecast. Reading the comments here, I also see that some see using Chromecast as a plus. To me, this is more of a bug! But it's a matter of perception, I suppose. I use the radio only for Pandora, so this is just an unnecessary layer of complication for me with no improved functionality. Sigh. I'm off to install what I need on my phone to make it work.

Edited to add: obviously, I do like Mondo and Mondo+ radios—I’ve bought three. I hope this issue with the Pandora app can be worked out eventually. The new radio is working fine using my phone to control it. I didn’t have any trouble getting Chromecast to work. But I’m not one to keep my cell phone with me all the time when I’m home—especially when I’m upstairs, for instance. I’d rather use an app and control Pandora from the radio itself. C’mon, Pandora.

If you want a internet radio this is the one to buy. Word wide radio at the touch of a button, More stattions than you knew existed. Great sound quality and easy to use. . I am addicted to nught radio and this was the perfect answer.

Bought mine refurbished from Grace Digital for a fraction of the cost of new. Arrived like new and packaged like new. This is a great little box. I use it as a clock radio in my bedroom. I keep reading that the sound is sub-par...but I don't see it. Maybe if you turn the volume up all of the way but mine rarely sees anything higher that 1/4 of the available volume. It could come down to what source audio people are listening to. Some internet radio stations broadcast low quality streams.

Pros:
-Great sound
-Color Screen with lots of info
-Alarm with 5 alarms being able to be saved.
-Large station list
-Has iHeartRadio access, Live 365 and Shoutcast.
-NPR access from all over the USA
-Has Chromecast built in. Once you start the cast from your phone/PC you can control track selection and play/pause right on the mondo+. The best sound quality seems to be when you are using the Chromecast. I haven't tried the built in audio player yet, but I'm sure FLAC files sound excellent on here as well.
-Bluetooth streaming uses HD AAC codec...so bluetooth audio is pretty high quality
-USB Port for local music storage or charging devices. I have a flashdrive with nature sounds loaded on it. It's perfect to fall asleep to when combined with the sleep timer function.
-Line in and also line out if you want to use an external amp and speakers.
-Has the ability to play music from a local DNLA server on your network

Cons:
-The control scheme is a bit cumbersome. A touch screen in a future hardware version would help.
-The dimmer doesn't really get dim enough for my taste. I like a dark room at night, it is completely off on the lowest setting. On the next to lowest setting it is illegible, on the next highest setting it is fine but the LCD screen has sub-par contrast ratio so a lot of light bleeds through what should be a black screen. This would be fixed by using an OLED screen, but then it would cost more to produce.
-Even though they have a large list of stations, I found some locals missing. They say you can email and request stations to be added, I'm going to try this and update later on how that goes.
-Battery not included. You have to buy a Lithium Ion battery pack to make this portable or to even have any form of battery back up for alarm clock use. The original from Grace Digital is pretty expensive. There is a 3rd party one available on Amazon that is about half the cost. I ordered it and have yet to receive it so IDK what the quality is like but the reviews on here look promising. EDIT: Got the battery and it seems to work fine.
-When I used my android cell phone as my alarm if I woke up early I had the option to cancel the alarm for that day and it would reset for the next day, the only option on the mondo+ is to turn the alarm off completely...then you have to remember to turn it on again before you go to bed that night.
-I missed an alarm one day because my WiFi was out so the station would not load...I feel like the software should realize this and use the buzzer as a backup...luckily I still have my cell phone alarm set as a backup alarm so I didn't miss work. This really needs to be addressed in the next firmware update...EDIT: This is actually how it already works. If the internet is out when the alarm is supposed to go off it will default to the buzzer...HOWEVER, if it begins to buffer the station and the internet goes out during that process it will just give up and display an error message.
-Wish I didn't have to buy a dongle for ethernet support....it takes up the USB port.

UPDATE 5/20/18: I built a PFSense router/firewall and suddenly I started having issues with certain stations not working, CBS Radio and iHeartRadio stopped working all together. Support was able to tell me what ports were needed but port forwarding didn't fix the issue. I started to have problems with my Xbox One at about the same time. When I began to research the xbox issues I found that by default PFSense has pretty strict outbound NAT rules. In order to get the Xbox One working I had to create a new outbound NAT rule. After doing that I figured why not try making a similar rule for my Mondo+ and viola...it finally works right. You can find a tutorial by searching youtube for "PFsense xbox". Substitute the IP for your Mondo in for the Xbox one in the tutorial.

reviews.reviewTitle: I listen to my favorite radio stations and podcasts without having to use my ...
reviews.reviewText:
The main reason I originally purchased this radio was because it worked with SiriusXM; but this radio does a lot more. I am able to listen to about anything. I listen to my favorite radio stations and podcasts without having to use my laptop. I take it to work with me and listen to it there as well. There is just not enough time in the day to listen to everything. The sound quality is really great as well.

Another plus for this unit is the customer support. I had a few issues early on and was amazed at how quickly and accommodating the folks at Grace Digital were. They worked with me and eventually got things to where I am quite pleased. They also keep me updated on new software releases. The only real negative for me is that I cannot save my internet connections since I travel back and forth to work and have two different internet connections. But once I put in the password credentials I'm good to go.

It was time to replace the ailing Logitech Squeezebox Radio we’d had and loved for years (and which had started acting wonky). I did a lot of reading up and settled on the Grace Mondo+. Emailed tech support ahead of time to find out whether it would work with our home NAS (where we store all our music) and they replied promptly and coherently that it would (I liked that the reply didn’t read like boilerplate or someone’s attempt to pass text through Google Translate). Bit the bullet and purchased the Mondo & Ethernet dongle/battery combo. Setup was extremely easy; the wireless wizard worked like a champ (although we will primarily use wired Ethernet). The iOS app is slightly lacking (crashes occasionally and isn’t quite as intuitive as I’d like), but the OSD is extremely straightforward. The sound quality is quite good; certainly good enough for a bedside clock radio. I wish there were more bundled apps; the nature sounds are a bit tinny. Calm Radio was a nice surprise and I ended up getting a paid subscription.
The Mondo has pretty much all the features I liked about the Squeezebox, with a much better/intuitive OSD and it sounds like there’s a lot of active support/development. I was sad when Logitech bought & then essentially scrapped Squeezebox, but the Grace Digital is an overall improvement. Additionally, it’s red, just like the old one. :)

reviews.reviewTitle: great product and service from Grace
reviews.reviewText: I have owned quite a few internet radios over the last 10 years. Grace Digital is certainly at the top of the list, along with Pure. They make a great, straightforward, and intuitive product which is easy to manage, set up, and operate. I have two older model Mondo's, so I decided to try this Mondo+ and I am glad I did, for several reasons. First, because the radio is a decided improvement over older models: nice, bright color display; clear, transparent sound; large, intuitive buttons. Second, because there was an issue with the radio's access to stations: I wrote to Grace customer service and heard back within the hour -- on a Sunday! We exchanged a couple of emails and I was told they would look into the matter. I heard back first thing Monday morning, confirming that there had been a glitch in the web-access which had been solved. I could now add all the stations I wanted, and was most pleased that Grace's customer service equaled the quality of their products. I value the portability of this model, adding a lithium battery to it, but it is quite a bit larger than other models and can't as easily be put into a suitcase, or carry around. But, other than that, this is a first-rate, quality product with customer care to match. Listed as refurbished, but looks and acts like new.

Radio works well. I purchased it to replace my Livio Radio because my favorite station moved to iHeart from CBS. I'm into streaming broadcast radio stations, not the streaming music services, This is a must have if you don't like AM noise on the distant stations. Streaming is FM quality. Best features are the 10 station/stream quick presets, USB for a thumb drive (can holds entire music collection), audio line out, and battery option for mobile use. Build quality could be a better, housing feels like cheap plastic, and could use a folding handle because the hand indent slot isn't a secure way to carry it. The remote is good quality, has real buttons, not one of those cheap bubble button remotes. Produces good sound for one room. The Grace Digital MyRadios+ website needs to have the ability to add folders (currently doesn't work) for stations for better organization, like Reciva Internet Radio has, this website needs some work. Google Play and the blue tooth speaker option work well with my iPhone 6s. I do have a Grace Solo Streaming Radio, which has held up well and outlasted the Livio because it supports iHeart streams. Always worry about the radio's built in streaming apps not being supported in the future, Grace not providing updates, or a mega media company taking their stations to a unique app. Anyone who has an iPhone or iPod touch can relate to that experience. If Grace stuffed this radio into an Ecoxgear like quality case, they'd get 5 stars out of me.

reviews.reviewTitle: This Is The Internet Radio You Want!
reviews.reviewText:
I shopped around for a long time before choosing this particular Internet radio and it is so much more than I ever expected. I was connected to our wifi and listening to music within minutes. I'm not big on reading user manuals but if you are thinking about this radio, go to the GraceDigital website and download the pdf manual. It is well laid out, easy to read, and clearly explains how to use the many features. It is by far the best user manual that I have ever read.

Access tens of thousands of Internet radio stations from Grace Digital's database, Shoutcast, Radio.com, iHeartRadio, NPR & Public Radio, SiriusXM, BBC, Calm Radio, and Live365. Those are just what's built in. You can also play your favorites from TuneIn, Pandora, Google Play Music, and Deezer as well as any other audio service or app that supports ChromeCast. The Mondo+ also supports Bluetooth so you can use it as a speaker. If that isn't enough, plug your mega digital music collection into the built-in USB port or access a UPnP or DLNA server. Your options for content are virtually unlimited. Sound quality is excellent and it is loud enough to fill a large room. It won't rattle your windows but is quite loud for a table radio.

Note: You need a streaming SiriusXM subscription to access that feature. One other plus on the XM portion of the radio, if you miss your favorite show you can "rewind" up to five hours and catch up on what you missed. There is also an option to start a song at the beginning when you tune to an XM music channel.

The IR remote control is easy to use, the Android app is great, and you can even register your radio on their website and manage your collection of favorite radio stations and podcasts. There are 10 user-programmable preset buttons on the radio that you can also access from the phone app. Set a sleep timer and up to five custom alarms. Wake up to a different station on weekdays or weekends if you want. You can even set the wake-up volume and number of minutes you want to snooze.

The Mondo+ is a well-designed, comprehensive package with excellent user experience in mind. I can't think of a single feature that is missing from this radio. Well done, Grace. Well done.

Now if they only made a handheld portable version of this, I'd buy it in a heartbeat! As it stands, I am now considering other home or outdoor audio products that they offer. They've got to be good and I am sure they are.

reviews.reviewTitle: Simple yet powerful audio streaming radio.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this Internet radio after purchasing the Sonicgrace K2 radio, which was more or less a terrible product, despite it presenting as a nice tablet/speaker combo, but old software and slow CPU make it frustrating.

This radio is far and wide a better radio, dedicated to streaming stations directly from the Internet, from thousands of stations built into the radio itself, but what makes it really appealing, is the online portal that allows you to add your own streams that are not available in the database! It plays virtually anything, from anywhere. Love the quick access to 10 presets. Robust firmware will do its best to resume disconnected streams. Sound quality is nice, given its size, and with the optional battery, there is many hours of play time. Ethernet option may be handy for some. Clock radio alarm is a nice touch. Feels like an actual radio. Use it every day.

Sadly it won't remember different Wifi networks, and requires you to manually connect to each wifi again, even if you've connected to it before. Might be an issue if you move the radio around frequently to different networks. Perhaps a firmware update will address this. There is a remote control app for your phone, but sadly it never detects my radio.

Overall a very strong 4 stars.

We are in a location with very poor radio reception so I needed to find something that would work in a block construction home up in the desert. This radio is perfect for getting an incredibly clear signal. Before, I had to use my cell phone and the iheart app, and with the tiny phone speaker, it was not ideal. I love the fact I can get stations from anywhere. We only use the radio feature and sleep timer, and haven't used all the programs/apps that are available.
There are a few things that if fixed or were different, would have pushed my rating to 5 stars:

1. I wish the buttons down the left side (home and those used to pre-tune a station) were lit, or at least a contrasting color so they could be seen easily.
2. When the radio is turned off and then turned on again later, the volume resets all the way to silent. We didn't realize that at first, and thought the radio was defective.

Twice we couldn't get it to work, but that could have been our error in pushing buttons that we couldn't see in the dark....(see #1 above), or, it just got a quirk and stopped working. A simple fix was to unplug, wait 20 seconds and replug it in.

Even with those minor issues, we love the Grace Digital radio, and will be ordering a second one. Highly recommend to anyone who loves AM radio but can't get a clear signal, or to those wanting to get a wifi connected / internet radio.

So this is my 3rd Grace Digital Radio, all have had problems connecting to WIFI and on two I have overcome the problems with adding an older router to my internet. At this house it will connect for maybe 5 minutes then not again for weeks at a time.

It clearly is a manufacturing issue as it keeps happening at all 3 of my different places with different internet providers.

Once it works it is a very nice radio, the real problem is getting connections to WIFI that stay connected. Very irritating.

reviews.reviewTitle: No Pandora without a cell phone or Ipad.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had several internet radios for the past 10 years or so. This by far is the best one I have
ever had the pleasure to own. It does lack Pandora, but for me this was not an issue
in its selection. Pandora can be received with the built in Chromecast or Bluetooth
and a cell phone, tablet device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Never minds the extras--it's an excellent Internet Radio
reviews.reviewText:
The description talks about smart speakers, Bluetooth, Chromecast, smartphones, etc. All these extras tend to obscure the fact that this is an excellent internet radio. Turn it on, connect to your WiFi, and that's it--you have access to hundreds of free internet radio stations. This includes many local radio stations that you can listen to even if you live out of their town. (I like WWOZ from New Orleans).
I already had a SiriusXM account for my car, so I upgraded to All-Access for $5 more per month so I can also listen to the SiriusXM stations, like Classic Vinyl and Grateful Dead.
One other feature important to me is the presence of RCA line out jacks on the rear of the unit. I used these to connect the Mondo to a receiver and two large stereo speakers for great sound. I would not have purchased the Mondo if it did not have this feature as I wanted music for a large room.
Overall, I am very happy with this radio as it is exactly what I wanted, it is simple to set up, and it works.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little radio ~ I connected it to external speakers for better sound
reviews.reviewText: I had the previous version of this, but it broke after 5 years. The only difference between the original and this one, is bluetooth capability. While the sound from the speakers is decent, it's much better when hooked up to external speakers. If you listen to Pandora a lot, try to purchase the older version, as that one allows you to set preset buttons for Pandora channels, whereas this one doesn't.

This machine makes it easy to listen to NPR anywhere in our house on the wireless network for free. It was easy to set up, connect, and set our favorite stations as presets. The one caveat is the power button. We bought two of these - one for a friend - and while our power button puts the machine into standby mode, her's will only power down by holding it for 3 seconds or more. Tapping the power button SHOULD go to standby. We have tried changing settings and restarting the setup from default but still no standby option. It is not so annoying that we would return it. It is still a really cool machine and we recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Robust solution for wireless audio connection, from Bluetooth to paid subscription provider and of course Internet Radio
reviews.reviewText:
It’s a complete and good audio device to listen wirelessly to a lot of radio and. Using providers
It has built in Chromecast that it’s really a plus, SiriusXM, 30000 channels of internet radio available, 10 presets, Bluetooth, remote control, good cel app and a battery pack (sold apart) that makes it portable
It’s easy to setup and it has a good sound, when I need some power sound I plug it on my receiver. In my opinion it’s the most robust solution available in the market for less than 180 us$

reviews.reviewTitle: This 2-year old tech is unusable as a Bluetooth speaker for TV; only marginal as a "clock radio"
reviews.reviewText:
Not an adequate Bluetooth speaker for TV:

This first shortcoming is likely due to the fact that this is 2-year-old tech, using BT 4.1 with no aptX or other Low Latency capability.

There are times when I want to wear headphones when watching TV in bed, and there are times when I prefer using a speaker. And at night, so as not to disturb others in the house even when using a speaker, I landed on using a smallish BT speaker bedside instead of the TV's full-on soundbar.

Prior to buying the Mondo+, I'd been using a really old, rechargeable/portable Aukey Bluetooth speaker when I wanted a speaker, and a set of Sony Bluetooth headphones (with BT 4.2 and aptX-LL ability), each tied to an Avantree Oasis transmitter (also with BT 4.2 and aptX-LL ability) that's connected to my TV via optical cable. When it pairs to a BT device, the Avantree Oasis picks the highest quality/speed codec/protocol/something-something. Even so, I had a little bit of a latency problem with my older Aukey BT speaker: maybe a half second off (which is understandable, given that speaker's old age).

I was hoping that replacing my old Proton clock radio set AND ditching the older BT speaker was going to simplify things and allow me some additional bedside table space. But nope. While I had a little latency with my really old Aukey speaker (and a little more than could be corrected with the Audio Sync feature on my TV, maybe a half second off, the Mondo+ is in a whole different league... bordering on 10 to 15 seconds behind the TV. Way outside the range of correction that my TV's audio sync allows (and probably outside the range of every TV out there... what TV is going to build in extra memory to allow for ridiculous delays like that?).

The latency problem is really so bad that it's quite useless as an Bluetooth speaker for my use. Considering a complete return if I'm able to find an Internet Radio with up-to-date BT. But if I can't find one of those that I like, I guess my fall-back will be to keep the Mondo+ and (a) get an aptX-LL speaker, or (b) buy an Avantree or other brand of aptX-LL receiver and hook it into the AUX input (and pray Grace hasn't slowed that input down somehow)... either way, I'm back to more stuff on my bedside table. Darn.

The interface makes this only marginal as an Internet radio; problems with their Portal:

Second major category of shortcomings: The Grace Portal and the radio's Interface both fall far short of expectations. I group these together because the portal could make up for some of the interface shortcomings, and vice versa, but nope. I was expecting the portal would let me set up stations for Presets. Nope.

And why would I think that? Well maybe because the marketing mentions of the portal read like the Grace portal makes setting up stations, podcasts, etc. easy, so you don't need to futz with the radio's interface directly. Except presets, apparently. So the some of the top-most user interface controls on this radio (the physical preset buttons sitting right there, on the outside, requiring nothing more than a push) are not addressable in the portal. Wow.

And what little the portal does seem to do is pretty poorly executed. Because on top of the portal's general useless-ness, it's also slooo-oooww-ww and seems pretty buggy (2 years after this radio's introduction, mind you... plenty of time to "work things out"). My attempts to save a station were greeted with fairly cryptic popups saying that you can't save a station and can only save podcasts or streams or something to that effect (which made me immediately wonder why would you put "save" buttons in the station section/tab if you can't save stations, esp. when there's a separate podcast section/tab?).

Then, despite the popups, stations I was told I couldn't save were actually saved as stations, apparently... so the popups were in error? But that's about the end of that potential positive: whatever you've saved in My Stuff is then literally *stuffed* several dial turn / dial click / dial scroll / dial clicks down in the My Stuff of the radio interface. Not in a preset button as I've said, but also nowhere near the top of the interface's Home screen entry. This is a multi-step process you'd probably not want to perform late at night or early in the morning, certainly, all the while asking yourself "now where did they stuff that?"

As it is, I consider trying to use their portal and the paltry results a complete waste of my time.

What would help immensely and actually make the portal useful: allowing users to actually customize the "home" screen (via the Portal), moving items not used (to a second screen?), and surfacing actual favorites (the number could be limited to 4 or 6 maybe?) to the top two rows of the Home screen. And, of course, give the portal the ability to set up and manage presets.

Just to be clear: Given that the Mondo+ is now 2 years old, I actually don't expect any of these problems to be addressed, especially the BT latency. I would expect that Grace has moved on to the next great thing, and this is all a low priority for them. So when I say "they need to do X" in this review, I really don't expect any of that to happen. Which is now one of my new, more realistic, much lower expectations for the Mondo+.

UPDATE (just 2 days later): And... yep. the buggy, slow portal is now completely down. Wow.

reviews.reviewTitle: About as good as it gets for internet radios
reviews.reviewText:
This is the third Grace radio that I have purchased. Grace seems to be the leader in actively seeking to provide the features customers want in their products and will even upgrade software to add wanted features. The only hiccup in the purchase was having to program the device from scratch as the prior radios used Reciva for their portal and Grace now runs their own portal. This took some time but was not difficult to do. I like having the increased number of presets (increased from 5 to 10), and the remote control means not having to use the manual scroll dial very often, which had ceased to function on my old radio and
led me to purchase this unit. The price was reasonable, and shipping time was terrific!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product and going to get even better
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this product to use in my office at my desk. I have a SiriusXM subscription and was looking for an internet radio I could connect to my account. SiriusXM used to have a desktop internet radio, but have since discontinued it. I also have Spotify Premium, so those two abilities were my primary focus. While it doesn't have the native spotify connect app built in yet, you can use your phone, computer, or tablet, to launch Spotify and cast to the mondo. From there, you can change tracks via the included remote, which is great. Grace digital told me that Spotify connect will be added in a future update which I'm excited about. Added bonus for me, I can stream music from Italy using the internet radio stations. It's lightweight, well built, and sounds AMAZING!

What you will have is a radio that works well for 5 to 10 days. After that, it decides that you don't live in America and stops working until you factory reset it. Then it decides you live in America, after all. Now you get to spend your time putting your channels back in. Until next week, when this pos decides that you don't live in America.

I've been around with the company, got a song&dance.

DON'T BUY

reviews.reviewTitle: Great built-in apps! Love this radio!
reviews.reviewText:
This radio does everything I wanted: a stand-alone radio with a wide choice of content and, especially, with presets. I’m very happy with this!

Before ordering, I spent a lot of time trying to determine the built-in “apps.” Amazon, various pictures, and even gracedigital.com are inconsistent. I ordered it and here are the out-of-the-box apps:
Grace Digital Internet
IHeartRadio
NPR and Public Radio
SiriusXM
Radio.com
SHOUTcast
BBC
Calm Radio
Live365
Podcasts
Sleep Sounds

Yes, I know I can use my iPhone to get more, but I like the idea of using this as a stand-alone Radio. I’m very satisfied with this selection of stations!

reviews.reviewTitle: Much Better Than Expected And HUGE Sound!
reviews.reviewText:
This is a great radio... Wifi, Bluetooth and a mass of internet radio stations.
The sound is very good and I was blown away by the sound from this relatively small unit.
Color screen that shows time, station and song being played.
You can alter the brightness of the screen so that when it's turned off it doesn't blind you, either bed side or under my TV.
When you connect the included rca plugs, it doesn't cut the music from the machine... Great, as sometimes I want to listen using the built in speaker and other days I want to crank it out through the sound bar!

What's even better is that you can have another Mondo+ in another room and connect them together so it plays the same channel throughout the house!
Think it sounds good with one unit, wait till you get another going!!
Zero lag and they sound amazing together.

Very happy with my purchase.
The app is a huge help too.
Makes searching and adding / changing features much easier.

You'll not be disappointed with this radio.
I can't believe I've lived without internet radio for this long!!

This was an early Christmas gift to myself. The sound from this radio I believe is better than Bose and I owe two Bose products. I subscribed to Serius XM and have been enjoying the Hallmark music everyday. The remote that came with unit did not work, I called the company and spoke to Linda who apologized and immediately sent out a new remote. It came cross country in two days and it works perfect. DO NOT HESITATE TO PURCHASE THIS RADIO. You will be enjoying great sound from the start.

reviews.reviewTitle: Chrome cast does not work with Pandora, and no one cares!
reviews.reviewText: Works fine as an internet radio. Completely nonfunctional for streaming Pandora. Chrome cast works about 10 percent of the time, and Bluetooth about 50 percent of the time. As usual, Grace says it’s Pandora’s fault, and Pandora pretends to not understand what the complaint is. Deeply regret the purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: this radio is the best! Well
reviews.reviewText: this radio is the best! Well, since I haven't tried all radios it's the best this 67-year old has ever experienced. Full list of features, regular software updates to improve the product and excellent HMI. Great radio.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mondo+ is an Awesome internet radio!
reviews.reviewText:
I've had the Grace Digital Mondo+ Internet Radio for over a month now. I am extremely happy with this radio. It is easy to use, the Wi-Fi connection is smooth and the sound quality of the internal speakers is great for a desktop radio. Scanning for local stations and setting presets was easy. Setting up a My Folder on my Grace Digital web account was simple and the stations I saved there are easy to access via the Mondo+ user interface. Chromecast is also very easy to use.

I'm using the Line Out signal to a Grace Digital BTAR512N integrated amplifier and muting the internal speaker. This configuration is a awesome package!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great internet radio, great sound, seriously awful software
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
I have been wrangling with Bose over their implementation of SiriusXM, which hasn't worked correctly for over a year - outages, cuts/drops, absolutely terrible. SiriusXM is my go-to for news and music, so I finally decided to find a radio that performed the same functions - I use this in my bedroom and it fits my needs exactly.

Pros:
+ Very easy to set up - I didn't have a problem with the dial-type input for username/password etc.
+ Good choice of music services available - some find it limiting but it covers just about everything I use, and I have access to my local digital radio stations.
+ Sound quality is pretty darn good. Some Sirius stations pop a bit but its not too bad, wish that didn't happen, but for what I need it to do, its great.
+ For a tiny little speaker its got some good features (sleep timer, alarm, play from USB, aux-in, stereo audio out). I'm pretty pleased overall with what's available to me given the price.

Cons:
+ Software seems iffy to me - I hooked it up in one spot for initial setup, then once I had presets configured, I unplugged it and moved it across the room. After it powered up and was at the Home screen, I pressed P1 - it went to the SiriusXM channel but then gave an error, something like "unable to play preset" and the screen froze. I had to power cycle the unit, and all my presets were gone.

Overall - really happy with the unit. I will keep an eye on the software, am hoping to keep this unit operating for a long time.

UPDATE 10/2: The software on this unit has the tendency to frustrate me - for example, after it moves to the clock/idle display, if I hit home, sometimes it gets stuck on the Alarms page, and I cannot get back to the home screen. I have to try about 5 or 6 times, pressing Home and Power before it will actually show me the Home screen. Also, it keeps saying the Sirius server is unreachable...when I can play Sirius on all my other devices.

Our power went out, this evening, and the time on the radio is wrong...BUT THERE IS NO OPTION TO MANUALLY CHANGE THE TIME. I go to Settings --> Alarm, Clock and Time but...no option to change the time. I try playing Sirius, but it keeps telling me the server is unreachable. Save your money, this software is too much of a hassle to deal with if something goes wrong. Knocking off two stars because I will never get these moments of my life back just spent trying to get this thing to work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Unreliable. Don't waste your money! STEER CLEAR OF THIS JUNK!
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased a previous version of this radio in mid 2014 and it died in early 2018. Figuring that electronics are flaky, and that there really weren't many other choices offering similar features, I bought the same radio again.

Big mistake.

It's now September 2019 and the radio is acting up.
> In the last week, the radio has missed several alarms. It recognizes the time, processes a bit and then reverts back to a clock, indicating the next alarm time.
>Lately it randomly stops streaming/playing.

The software is up to date and rebooting does not help, so I'm writing off this purchase.

When the radio worked, it worked well with nice sound and display but there are clearly quality issues. I have had a Sangean DDR-63 table radio with similar features since 2013 and it has been rock solid.

Save your money and steer clear of this junk.

reviews.reviewTitle: Elated! I've never seen a radio like this.
reviews.reviewText:
This radio is awesome. I'm out in the middle of the Pacific, (outer island of Hawaii) and I can FINALLY get great radio. Not just good, great.

Pros:

Very well made. Great display for station search. The display font is very appealing. Very clean sound quality. Ease in setting up. ( I did it in about 15 minutes without opening the book.) Ease in station search. The sleep timer is very easy to set in 10 minute increments. Just push a stand alone button once for every 10 minutes. If you want minutes turn the big knob. Volume is the stand alone knob on top. The display light is controlled with the big knob which changes in increments down to off. I think the sound fades to almost nothing right before the sleep timer shuts off the radio but I'm not sure yet. That puts me right to sleep. The remote is easy to tell which way is up in the dark. The down side has the batteries and the up side is thinner.

Cons:

When on sleep timer I can turn the display light all the way off. When the radio shuts off the display light comes back on with the time displayed. Maybe if I open the book I can figure out how to keep it off all night. ( I don't need to know what time it is until next year.) I prefer darkness all night until the Hawaiian birds wake me up.
The station buttons on the face of the radio are hard to feel in the dark, making it difficult to change stations while laying in bed. I think the remote will be good for that once I have that memorized.

I can't tell you how the alarm works because I'll never need it. With how well this radio is made and the thoughtfulness they put into its use I'd bet it's close to perfect.
I was advised to just use my phone for internet radio and boy am I glad I forked out the money for this instead. I bought it mostly because of the sleep timer and that exceeded all my expectations.
Next, I'll buy a FM transmitter to transmit ANYTHING to my shop.

All in all, I'm thrilled with this radio. I think I've never been so pleased with any other Amazon purchase. (can you tell?) I'd highly recommend this radio to everyone outside a big city's range. Kinda hard to fork out the money, kinda spendy, but now that's the farthest thing from my mind.
I'm listening to Australia, Los Angeles, San Fransisco and Seattle. MSNBC too. My search for more continues. I'm so over small town radio. Finally!
Buy it and enjoy.

reviews.reviewTitle: They changed something that was was working fine to something that doesn't
reviews.reviewText: They changed the original model which I own and works as advertised. I needed a second radio for my studio so I bought this. Thinking it would function the same. It didn't. I am computer savvy( I.T. at large 911 Comm Center) and I could not get this device to connect to the outside world. I made several calls to their support center and they didn't have any useful suggestions so I returned it. I am just going to buy a very good transistor radio. Very disappoint that they felt they had to muck around with something that worked and changed it into something that doesn't.

Beautiful looking radio.
I've bought several internet radios over the years.( I use a squeezebox myself.) This was for my wife and she really loves it. The sound is better than my squeezebox, higher volume and a richer sound. I don't quite see the fuss about the navigation, just not happening on our radio. Its better than the squeezebox but then it should be as it is later in the development world. I think the looks are very similar. My wife is not using some of the features that others are complaining about so can't comment on those. Another great feature is the battery. I bought the generic battery (seems to work fine) and you can move he radio around and use wherever you like. I find it a but pricy, but the radio is a lot of value. My wife is quite happy with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: A nice radio when it's willing to play.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased a refurbished Mondo+ from Grace in May, when my Sangean (and all Frontier-Silicon based radios) lost the ability to store and access favorite channels and podcasts. I was amazed in that I received what could only be described as a brand new radio and was very happy with my purchase. The radio is a very nice design that was a pleasure to use. A few firmware updates were automatically applied with no noticeable impact. There is no way to turn that off I could find.

The first sign of trouble was on 7/20/19 after 6 weeks of ownership. A “Network timeout error” displayed on the screen and play stopped. I called the support number and was directed how to do a soft reboot which worked. The radio played well for a few weeks following this incident. Since then however the radio will at times simply stop playing. The play icon changes from the triangle to the egg timer and no changing of channels, playing with the menu or normal powering off will get it to recover. A hard reboot (unplug, wait, replug) will bring it back to life.

The frequency of these stop-playing incidences is increasing and finally when it happened only a couple of hours after the latest hard reboot, I decided to query support by email. The response was communication with the router had failed and pointed me to the warranty-return form. Being out of warranty it's $33 plus shipping to give them a third shot at this radio. (Recall it is refurbished.) Considering how often I see this problem listed by other reviewers, I have little confidence that I will get a long lasting functioning radio in return. I think I stand an equal chance that this is simply a firmware problem that they might eventually get right or if it is hardware related a recall might be in order as I am not alone. I also have a now working with favorites Sangean WFR-28C that does not stop playing on it's own, so doing without the Mondo+ isn't painful. (Thank you Frontier-Silicon!)

I will continue to use the Mondo+ connected to a convenient power switch often enough to test whether a future update corrects the stop-playing problem and will update this review should that occur. At this time I would not recommend this radio to friend or foe.

Update: 10/23/19. I used the radio sparsely since the original review but it continues to simply stop playing and shows the hour-glass icon when that happens. I've included a picture. You might notice that the wifi icon shows a strong signal which causes me to doubt what the support person suggested. The only way to get it going again is to remove the power adapter. For as little as I now use it I was still surprised the problem showed up again so soon. I have therefore lowered the rating to one star, because a radio that just stops playing regularly doesn't deserve anything above the minimal rating.

After losing access to my favorite net radio stations (Yamaha decided to eliminate something that was working well), I contacted Calm Radio to discuss alternatives and they recommended Grace Radio. After much research, I decided on the Mondo+. The product reviews and questions posted on Amazon were very informative but I had a couple of questions that were not answered so I sent email to Grace support on Saturday. Much to my surprise, I got a reply with answers a short time later and I submitted an order Saturday afternoon. I received my radio Monday morning and had it up and running Monday afternoon with access to everything I lost and much more. Again, customer support was very responsive and helped me with a couple of issues I encountered with setup. The radio itself has amazing audio quality and volume but my plan was to connect the radio to an AV input on my Yamaha to use my existing amp and speaker setup, and that was easy to do and works very well. I now have an additional remote in my pile of AV remotes but net radio is my primary source of entertainment and that is a very small price to pay for a great solution to a significant problem.

reviews.reviewTitle: Technically a great product, but the station selections are more limited than previous versions
reviews.reviewText: I love the technical aspects of this radio. Grace Digital obviously listened to their previous customers and made the interface smoother and easier to use. If we look only from that perspective, I love this radio. Of course, I bought it because I own an earlier model and liked it. However (and this is a big deal to me), the available stations are not as plentiful as they were on older versions. I don't know why or how, but stations that I routinely listen to on the old radio (which still works) are simply "not found" on this one! That limits my selection significantly. And then there's the "Pandora issue." The previous version has a Pandora app that I use all the time. This one doesn't. In order to get Pandora on this radio, I have to sort of "channel" it through my desktop to this radio. However, the reason I bought these radios in the first place was so that I could listen to internet radio without my desktop, so this kind of defeats the purpose. And then there's the "registration issue:" Instructions say you can register it to get all kinds of control over loading stations. Except the instructions don't work, and the website for the Mondo+ doesn't exist. Pretty sloppy if you ask me. Technically, it's a great product. But it's significantly more limited than previous versions in that what I listen to on it is significantly more limited. That's why I (reluctantly) only give three stars to this radio. I doubt if I would have bought it if I had known. But your experience may vary.

I had heard about internet radio, and wanted to give it a try. What a nice job this radio does. I plugged it in and it asked for my modem password, which I did not have, called Cox Cable, entered the Modem Password, and off in running. I just have it running a few days, but the stations are almost limitless. I am hung up on a station in Texas that plays oldies and takes requests all day, and I suggest everyone give it a try. You will not be disappointed.

Wow! It is really nice to move to internet radio. I found this radio to have excellent connectivity to the nursing home WiFi, to be reasonably easy to program, and to have excellent sound.

I purchased this for my 87-year-old mother, who is in a nursing home with limited eyesight and hand flexibility. I set up the radio for her, and she mainly just adjusts the volume. She really listens to only one radio station, an AM local.

What keeps me from giving this 5 stars is that the snooze/sleep bar is right in front of the volume control on the top of the radio. My mother often bumps this bar when she's adjusting the volume, and then the radio turns off automatically in 10 minutes. My mother then has to call an aide to help her turn the radio back on.

Other than the snooze/sleep bar issue, we've been very happy with this radio. The clarity of sound, no more static on the AM station, is really fantastic.

reviews.reviewTitle: MAJOR LIMITATIONS AS A TRUE INTERNET RADIO
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
Although this radio is well made and of good quality I gave it only one star because of its severe limitations as an actual internet radio.
It cannot connect to Pandora, Spotify, or any other streaming music service.
Nor does it recognize all NPR stations despite having a dedicated "NPR/Public Radio" channel on their menu. There are individual stations such as WCAI which simply do not exist on this radio.
Customer support is perfunctory.
I feel this product is described in a misleading fashion which nowhere states its inability to connect to music streaming services.
If this matters to you then do not buy this radio.

I love the ability to pick up stations from all over the world. It works great as a bedside clock radio and is portable to make it easy to use anywhere in the house. There are 2 relatively minor points that could use improvement. First, there are 10 buttons for favorite stations. They also have a file called "my stuff" where you can store additional stations. But to do that you to register on their web site and do the search and store on the site. I t would be much more convenient to be able to do this directly on the radio. Second, the radio can serve as a Bluetooth speaker to stream from an app on your smart device. But it doesn't work the other way around. The sound quality is reasonably good, but given all of the music stations available it would be nice to have the ability to stream to a more advanced Bluetooth speaker. Despite these relatively minor points, this is a great product and I highly recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: False Advertising - No Pandora App pre-installed
reviews.reviewText: I was looking for a device with apps built in so i could play streaming music, primarily Pandora without draining my phones battery. I saw the ad on Amazon showing the device with a PANDORA app icon on the display screen. I was sad when I got the radio and found out that it didn't have the Pandora App built in, but only works with Pandora if you stream it there via ChromeCast. So, after figuring out how to stream it from my phone, which was what I was trying to avoid, I get an e-mail from Pandora telling me that I was streaming from more than one device at a time, my phone and chromecast, and if I continued to stream it from multiple devices, I would need to pay for another yearly subscription, so I can't even stream Pandora to the mondoplus without paying a higher fee and still draining my phones battery. Kept the device for regular radio streaming, but extremely dissapointed in the less than honest advertising from GraceDigital. Paid $175 but only consider it worth about $99.

The system is easy to set up and works wonderfully, but I do have two minor issues:
1. When setting up user names and passwords, the alphabet reverts back to "A" after each input rather than staying
where the last letter entered was. No big deal; it just takes longer to enter the data.
2. There are a lot of inputs into the system, but only one output (I play this unit through my amplifier/speaker system
for better sound). The only output is the headphone jack. An adaptor for this was provided so I could connect to the
amplifier with the RCA jacks, but there was no clue given that this adaptor could be used in this matter (there was
also a 3.5 MM input in the back of the unit so I assumed this was for another input rather than output). Perhaps
another RCA OUTPUT would be helpful and give better sound quality. Regardless, even without the amplifier, the
output of the unit is quite good on its own.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: the stations already programmed in the radio suddenly vanish and won't show up on the search anymore.
Easy to use. Great features-- like dimming screen at night . So many internet radio channels, and much clearer reception than with conventional radio.
I love this radio! I just got it today and so easy to set it up. I also ordered the rechargeable battery to make it portable. I can't wait for the warmer weather to bring it outside!

i bought this item because my other table wifi siriusxm radio screen went out after 10 years and it still worked. i buy this item and it cannot hold a channel to save it's life. i am constantly having to reset it. when headphones are in the alarm only works through headphones. the screen is so bright at low level my wife complains. i want to return this piece but i cannot due to the deadline.

I purchased this radio in May, 2018. With technology, I always wait to post reviews to see how it performs over time. Initially I would have given this unit 5 stars. However, in the past several weeks the radio, regardless of station chosen, loses connectivity and requires a reboot. Since I only listen at night in bed, this is a royal PIA. I have enterprise level wifi equipment and am an IT guy. This is the only, of very many, connected devices that is problematic. I have not contacted the manufacturer and the firmware is current. Unfortunate as it is a pleasure to use otherwise. I don't think I would have purchased this unit had I known.

Update 7-18-2019: New issues for several months now.
1) The volume of each station varies up and down as you listen requiring a reboot to rectify.
2) At times the station appears on screen but there is no audio at all. It then requires a reboot to return the audio.
3) Newest and latest issue - All presets disappear and the screen says empty on each preset number. It then requires a reboot to get them back.

All in all, a problem prone device. Having said that, when it works it is wonderful. If I was aware of a superior radio without problems I would buy it now.

I have had Grace Mondo radios for years. But the new Mondo+ doe not offer Pandora. To receive Pandora you have to stream it via Chromecast through your computer or phone. Since I use these radios as clock radios using the timer feature, and use them to receive Pandora exclusively, having to stream just makes life too difficult. On the positive side, it does offer SiriusXM if you have an online subscription.
A great device! Perfect for adding tunes to the bedroom.

For several years I had the Logitech Squeezebox. For about 5yrs it would inevitably have problems about once a month. Usually it would disconnect with my wi-fi completely out of the blue and then my alarm wouldn't come on the next morning. At first I thought it might be my wi-fi, but it wasn't. Another annoying aspect of that radio was the interface. It was just a total pain to maneuver, showing you one line at a time as you turned the knob. There were other little things which were very annoying.

I finally gave up on it and took a chance with this - and I'm very very glad I gave them a chance. This radio has everything I wanted. First of all, it's much more reliable with the wi-fi. It doesn't just all of the sudden go offline. Next, the interface is much more intuitive. Granted, it also is reliant upon a knob which you rotate to maneuver, but the 3.5" screen makes a big difference. Scrolling through a menu and a list make a huge difference than a single-lined dot-matrix screen. Finding internet stations is much easier.

And another huge addition is the Bluetooth. Being able to control it with another device (phone, pad) adds a bunch to its value. The Squeezebox only had an aux cable - and you need to manuever to the right spot to allow it to be controlled by your other device. This just automatically skips over to your device when you choose it on your phone and start playing. It's basically a wireless speaker at that point.

And it's also got a bunch of little settings which had to convenience, such as the ability to adjust the brightness of the screen. You can even make the screen display at different brightness at different times of the day.

I'm happy for Grace. They sound like a great little company. I hope they're able to continue for a while. I have a feeling the internet radio market is about to start getting more players.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
I was getting tired of my trusty old Sony clock radio from high school. It's obnoxious BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP was wearing thin and I was over being jolted awake.

So, I gave this radio a try. So far, I'm pleased. I really like that I can set various stations as favorites. For example, you could have an iHeart Radio station as favorite 1. Or an XM station as favorite 2, so on and so forth. I especially love how configurable the alarms are. You could wake up to anything from XM's BPM to an Alaskan Wind Storm!

2 things I wish were better:
*I wish the display wasn't so bright at night. Even on its lowest setting, the unit lights up the room like crazy. It would be nice if I could configure the color of the clock to, say, red. And turn down the back light so it isn't so blinding.

*I wish the feet were a little stickier. Having it on a night stand which has a million coats of poly urethane on it it will tend to slide to the point you need a hand to hold the radio every time you push a button.

It'd also be nice if it came with a battery backup pack included.

Setup took a little longer than a few minutes. But it was super easy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy setup out of the box
reviews.reviewText: I've only had it for a couple of days now, but so far it's been working fine. All I had to do so was enter the Wi-Fi password, update the software and start listening to music. I searched for local channels and it found my usual go to local station. The Dove WDUV. I'm still learning the user interface. The only problem I've experienced was the Android remote control app. It doesn't work at all. It will not find the radio on the same local Wi-Fi network. It seems a lot of people have the problem if you read the reviews. I really wanted to use the phone app.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very Nice Radio Design but no ethernet jack
reviews.reviewText:
I only gave it 3 stars since it is missing an ethernet jack. The WiFi connection is not that great. I like the interface. It would be nice to have night lights on the 10 station presets, but adding felts to keys 1, 3 and 5 made key access easy in the dark. Be sure to get a Grace Digital online account since this allows you to find stations online and then create directories such as Comedy, News, Old_Time_Radio and Music with your favorite stations. Now you have access to much more than the 10 presets. The Clock and Alarm features were easy to set. I moved the radio away from my bedside night stand to receive less WiFi radiation.

Now I get free and sometimes clear radio stations from all over the world. They should add an ethernet jack.

reviews.reviewerName: David Lida, author of First Stop in the New World: Mexico City, Capital of the 21st Century
reviews.reviewTitle: I'm very happy with this radio
reviews.reviewText: For years I had a Logitech UE Smart Radio, which died a few months ago. Logitech no longer makes or repairs these, so I wanted to buy a new internet radio. After a little research, I chose the Grace Digital Mondo due to what I consider its reasonable price and all the good reviews and press it received. I'm very happy with it. It's easy to set up and program. You can choose up to ten "favorite" stations that you get with the press of a button or two, and many more if you register with them on the internet. It's lightweight and therefore easy to carry from room to room. I have one tiny complaint, and this is something that should only concern people who, like me, live outside the U.S. -- the battery cannot be shipped everywhere via Amazon. I had to get it shipped to a friend in the U.S. who came to visit me. This was not a huge inconvenience, but it's something to take into account if you don't live in the U.S. Again, I'm very happy with this radio.

Great radio to have to hear radio stations from around the world with ease. I do have a shortwave radio and still enjoy that, but there are much less international broadcasters on shortwave than years past, and this does have digital quality. Also works great with SiriusXM capability if you have a subscription. Regardless, an excellent and fun radio to have. Highly recommended to get the ACC-IRCLI rechargeable battery with it as that is the only wan to make it portable. If you get this radio, make sure to let it get its occasional firmware updates to keep its feature set up to date. You also might want to look at the book "The Worldwide Listening Guide."

This radio is much improved over the previous version, sound is much improved, feature set is better, and with the built in Chromecast music service choices are almost endless. Top that off with the fact that they have announced that new features are yet to be incorporated in future firmware releases. This is a great internet radio.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent radio with many features, although a little complicated
reviews.reviewText: An upgrade after ten years with my previous Logitech Squeezebox radio, although very similar in look and features. In many ways this is a superior design, with the ability to use other apps such as Sirius, etc. Programming is less than intuitive, but once you have set your presets (a doubling up using the shift key for buttons of favorite stations ) it is relatively straightforward for daily use. A few shortcomings have been ably described by previous reviewers and, annoyingly, it does not appear to memorize WiFi login passwords, but in my experience, this is the best table top Internet radio of its kind out there right now. The Tivoli units look sharp but are more for looks and not sound and feature-laden advantages of the Grace Mondo+.
